availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Appointments by the Governor, Civil Appointments, 1862-1863

creation.placeName: New York City, New York County, New York

body.p:
State of New York
City and County of New York } :SS

I the undersigned Edward Bissell of the City County and State of New York having ^been^ on the first day of May A D 1863 (three) appointed by the Governor of the state of Kentucky a Commissioner of Deeds &c of said state of -- Kentucky, in and for the City County and State of New York. Do hereby solemnly swear that I will well and faithfully, honestly and impartially discharge, execute and perform, all the duties of my office and station, as such Commissioner of Deeds as aforesaid, under and by virtue of my said appointment, and the Laws of the said state of Kentucky; and that the following impression from a seal, is a true faithful and correct impression of, and from, my official seal, as such Commissioner of Deeds &c as aforesaid: So help me God!

Edward Bissell.
[of No 271. Broadway, New York City]

figure.ab:
EDWARD BISSELL,
COMMISSIONER
OF
DEEDS &c
FOR
Kentucky
IN CITY
-- & --
STATE OF NEW YORK.

body.p: Subscribed and sworn to before me, the undersigned authority of the State of Kentucky in and for the city county and state of New York, by the above named Edward Bissell at and in the city of New York, this -- 6th day of May A, D, 1863 (three

A Witness my hand and seal of office
J. B. Nones
Commissioner of Kentucky for New York.

New York
Comr of Deeds
Oath
Edwd Bissell
Filed May 9. 1863.
